content: Yes, although adult Emperor Penguins have few natural predators in Antarctica, their eggs and chicks are at risk from predators such as the Southern Giant Petrel, the Skua, and the Leopard Seal. These predators can take advantage of the relatively open areas around the Emperor Penguin's rookeries to prey on their eggs or chicks while the adults are feeding in the ocean. However, Emperor Penguins have many adaptations, such as laying their eggs in the winter and huddling together for warmth, that help them to survive in the harsh Antarctic environment.
